questions.question: What does the Chinese Remainder Theorem state?
options: If you know the remainders of an integer n when divided by several integers, you can determine the remainder of n when divided by the product of those integers.
If you know the remainders of an integer n when divided by several integers, you can determine the value of n itself.
If you know the remainders of an integer n when divided by several integers, you can determine the greatest common divisor of those integers.
None of the above.

questions.question: What is the key condition for the Chinese Remainder Theorem to hold?
options: The divisors must be all even numbers.
The divisors must be all odd numbers.
The divisors must be pairwise coprime (no two divisors share a common factor other than 1).
The divisors must be multiples of each other.

questions.question: Which of these is an example of the Chinese Remainder Theorem in action?
options: Knowing that a number leaves a remainder of 2 when divided by 3, 3 when divided by 5, and 2 when divided by 7, we can deduce that the remainder when divided by 105 (3*5*7) is 23.
Knowing that a number is divisible by 3 and 5, we can conclude it is divisible by 15.
Knowing that a number leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 2, we can conclude it is an odd number.
None of the above.

questions.question: What is one practical application of the Chinese Remainder Theorem?
options: It helps in finding the largest prime factor of a number.
It is used to decrypt secret messages.
It aids in efficient computation with large integers by breaking them into smaller computations.
It is used to prove the existence of infinitely many prime numbers.

questions.question: Which ancient mathematician is credited with the earliest known statement of the Chinese Remainder Theorem?
options: Pythagoras
Euclid
Sunzi
Diophantus
